ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned a lot about women's history from multiple eras and multiple cultures.

1. don't bring presentist or 21st-century feminist assumptions to course readings or writing papers
2. women's history contains a lot of intersectionality of race, gender, and class; womanhood doesn't bound all women
3. how to read historical sources and recognize biases
Being able to draw comparisons between two themes in different countries and expanding my point of view in discussion from a singular country/society.
I learned how to think critically about women's history, what that even is, and women's role in society across many time periods and cultures.

I furthered my knowledge of women's history from the perspectives of multiple cultures. From the medicalization of women's bodies to the birth of the feminist movement, the material learned in this course provided a comprehensive view of perceptual changes surrounding womanhood. I also gained insight into how to become a better writer. Professor Tannenbaum gave great feedback about how to improve each paper and how to fairly represent historical sources.
I learned more about the nature of women's history and how it compares and differs from other paths of history.

I developed a great understanding of women's roles in a variety of societies and cultures around the world, including those that I'd rarely learned about in history courses, such as premodern Indonesia and Meiji era Japan. Women's work, women in politics, feminisms, and women's social and sexual lives all featured.
Critical reading skills, as well as adapting to a safe and inclusive seminar format

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Really liked most of the discussions. Tannenbaum's readings were mostly interesting (although a few were kind of bland). Everyone in the class had interesting insights into each topic, which made classes enjoyable.

strengths: FASCINATING topics and material (we talked about witchcraft, the invention of the vibrator, women's economic work, cultural constructions of women's bodies and sexuality, and so many more interesting topics); 98% of the readings were honestly so interesting and well-written; professor Tannenbaum is a great discussion leader, she poses the right questions to direct us in different directions; workload: 60-80 pages of reading and 2 reading responses per week (I felt it was a good amount of work but still manageable)
weaknesses: make the seminar environment more encouraging for students who may be shy or insecure in speaking up

Strengths- consistency in workload with two readings for class was very manageable. I also felt a great deal of community in this course.
Weaknesses- sometimes discussion felt like it was dragging on. I really enjoyed when we had new content in class like photos, articles, etc. and think this would be a good improvement to the course.

Strengths: Discussion was facilitated very well! The professor was really skilled at pushing us in all the right ways on how to think about women's history and question the ways we have thought of women in the past. It was a really homey feeling in class (which is hard on Zoom). Also loved the multi-cultural aspect of the readings and the FIELD TRIPS!!
Weaknesses: Would've loved to see Latin-American and Black-American voices in our readings (I felt like these groups were very underrepresented)
I would've preferred to receive more clear feedback on assignments.

Excellent discussions; I felt that the first-year seminar format really made me feel closer with the professor and the other students than any other class I'd been in. The selection of readings for each course were varied and interesting, incorporating a wide variety of cultures. The week on witchcraft in colonial New England, featuring selections from Professor Tannenbaum's own book, was a highlight.
Course is very heavy in complex readings, often limiting discussion to only one aspect of what was read in a certain week rather than all

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: no strengths or weaknesses regarding covid. Great transition to online.
I liked having discussion posts.
Seminar format was fantastic done virtually!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Professor Tannenbaum engaged the class in intriguing conversations and every class was very eye opening. Take this class if you want to learn more about womens history and history in general!

Absolutely adored this class. It was a stimulating environment in which I felt totally comfortable to express myself. I came out of each class inspired by the content I'd learned but also by the people in the class whose thoughts and opinions were wonderful to listen to.

Yes, very interesting subject material and great professor. She is willing to help if you ask for it and the material itself is mostly very engaging. Also think it is a good seminar class for more introverted people or people who are more anxious about speaking in class. At first, I was nervous about speaking during discussions, but everyone, including Tannenbaum, is very open minded and I think the class is well suited for all types of people.
Yes! Especially students interested in but not committed to wgss as a major because it was a great introduction to themes in women's history.

Yes!! It was one of my favorite classes at Yale and really challenged me to think critically about women, especially those outside of the Western world. Professor Tannenbaum did a great job facilitating discussion and making the classroom a safe space for us to talk about these history topics that remain very relevant to this day. It's an amazing way to meet other first-years and form friendships through the small class environment. Overall 10/10 experiebce

I would absolutely recommend this course to all students, regardless of what major they are in. The study of women and gender as a whole is essential for social and cultural analysis. This course pushes students to question the norms surrounding femininity that are widely accepted today, and informs of historical ideals that have led to the development of modern societies. Besides learning more about history that is often erased from the common curriculum, students are able to easily engage with the course material, as readings and assignments give students the liberty to explore their own interests and interpret texts as they choose.
I would definitely recommend this course to other students regardless of their intended major.
Yes, great course, but this will be the most writing a writing credit can be.
Absolutely. This was the best course of my first year, and I feel that it's helped me develop my writing and discussion skills tremendously.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminar
